entry.title: Announcing the SAP Analytics Cloud Home Page Redesign
entry.content:
At SAP, we're always looking for ways to make your experience better, more efficient, and more enjoyable. That’s why I'm thrilled to introduce our Redesigned SAP Analytics Cloud Home Page for the 2025 Q3 QRC release.

What is the New SAC Home Page?

The new SAC Home Page is designed to help you navigate and access key resources more seamlessly. With this updated interface, you can now enjoy a more intuitive layout, enhanced customization options, and improved performance for a smoother experience. 

Why You’ll Love It

Here are just a few reasons why the new SAC Home Page is a game-changer:

  • Enhanced Usability: Streamlined navigation makes it easier to find what you need, when you need it.

  • Personalized Experience: Customize your SAC Home page to prioritize the tools and insights most relevant to you.

  • Faster Performance: Optimized loading times ensure a more efficient workflow.

A total of five new cards are being introduced to the SAC home page. Let's take a closer look at them.

Onboarding Card

It provides a brand new onboarding experience. It includes links to helpful tutorials and learning courses, so you can get up to speed with the product in no time.

The card also comes with a search bar where you can type in questions you might have directly. It will lead you to our help documentation with the most fitting results for your query.

Quick Actions Card

It lets you select up to four quick actions from a broad selection, to add to your home page, for quick access to your most frequent daily tasks like creating a story or a model.

Just Ask Card

What's also new is that Just Ask now comes as a card with an advanced search bar. Powered by generative AI, it lets you initiate searches from the home page using natural language.

Not only does it let you enter your search, but it also lets you refine it by selecting your data and adding attributes. The Just Ask feature then opens and pre-populates your search from the card with results.

Resources Card

To help you explore our community, see upcoming updates, and learn more about SAC roadmap, we've created the Resources card.

This card provides quick and easy access to various types of information about the product. You can find everything from a sample custom widgets to business content, release updates, and more.

Favourites Card

The final card we'd like to introduce is the Favourites card. It displays files you've favourited and allows you to filter them.

You can find the filter settings in the card's submenu. The dialog lets you filter by all file types and you can choose to apply one or multiple filters for the card.

Besides all of our new cards, we've also improved and revamped some of our existing cards, which are : 

  • Calendar highlights
  • Recent files
  • Featured files
  • and Data Change Insights

The cards all come with search functions and improved filtering experiences and capabilities. So you can display and find the information you're looking for easily.

How to Customize it 

All of our cards are repositionable, and the card layout is responsive. If you decide to reposition a card, all the other cards will adjust accordingly. For further customization, you can open the home page settings dialog. It's still available via the user profile. However, for quicker access, we've added a "Customize" button to the top right area of the home page.

The home page settings dialog provides you with the option to select your default home page experience and show and hide functions for all the available cards.

What's next ?

Within the next releases we will introduce:

  • New cards
  • Enable the card Resizing 
  • Introducing cards dedicated to the SAC Administrator 
  • New user profile settings
  • New Theming features 

Stay tuned for more updates !

entry.content:
介绍

借助SAP分析云，设计人员和开发人员在创建故事时可以使用大量灵活的功能。然而，考虑这些复杂的故事可能对​​移动设备​​中的用户体验和运行性能产生的影响是十分重要的。

​​在本篇博客中，我们将重点介绍一些最佳实践指南，供设计人员和开发人员在为移动设备创作故事时参考。

最佳实践

为了提供流畅且用户友好的体验，设计人员和开发人员可以参考一些最佳实践指南。这些指南可分为三部分：

  • 理解移动设备硬件规格
  • 故事简化（对象与高级特性）​
  • 移动设备上的测试与验证

理解移动设备硬件规格

设计人员和开发人员应该熟悉SAP分析云的移动硬件规格。这是因为根据整个业务中可用的设备，应遵循不同的最佳实践指南。以下是每个设备的一些推荐的最佳实践指南：

故事简化（对象与高级特性）​

设计人员和开发人员应该了解在移动设备上向消费者展示哪些信息是重要的。因为与笔记本电脑不同，移动设备的屏幕尺寸和设备内存有限。

技巧1. 降低仪表盘整体复杂度​

从便利性角度出发，将所有信息整合至单一故事颇具吸引力。然而，此举可能导致​​信息过载​​，并​​使移动设备体验复杂化​​。因为页面数量与对象的组合会增加故事大小，进而导致运行处理时间的增加。

注意：当与设计数据相关的小部件数量和页面数量超过建议数量时，设计时会发出警告。

  • · 限制单页上数据相关小部件的数量：建议将这些内容分散到多个页面中。对于流式布局面板或响应式布局，可以使用响应规则配置来根据设备隐藏特定的小部件。
  • 限制故事页的数量：建议同时限制单个故事板内的页面总数。创建更精简的故事，并利用​​故事之间的超链接​​实现跨故事导航。

技巧2. 限制“高消耗”可视化对象的数量

鉴于移动设备内存普遍低于Web端，且不同移动设备内存容量差异显著，​​因此严格控制内存密集型微件的数量十分重要​​。各微件类型的单位权重值详情可参阅SAP帮助门户文档。

以下为高消耗微件示例：

  • ​​地理可视化对象​​
    • ​​表
    • ​​时间序列统计图​​
    • ​​自定义微件

注意：对于​​地理可视化对象，还有进一步的建议，即​​每页至多包含一个​​地理可视化对象​​，​​且在该可视化对象中限制图层数（不超过三个）。

注意：一个故事中筛选器的数量能会影响移动设备上的性能

技巧3. 限制复杂脚本的使用

使用优化体验，有许多可用的 API，允许开发者创建开箱即用的自定义应用或工作流，这意味着低效的脚本或复杂的脚本会对移动设备体验产生影响，原因在于其会增大处理负载并引发移动设备闪退。

在各种移动设备上进行测试和验证

​注意：以上提示均属最佳实践指南。鉴于移动设备硬件配置差异显著，必须逐台验证使用体验。

技巧1. 预览和测试

故事中的设备预览功能是验证多设备适配效果的实用工具，但若需确保界面响应灵敏、体验流畅易用，物理设备预览与测试环节依然至关重要。

技巧2. 性能和内存验证

作为技巧1的扩展，侧重点在于​​要求跨多种设备的（如3, 4, 6, 8+ GB内存），对故事进行充分测试​​。这能为用户​​规避内存溢出（OOM）问题提供额外保障​​。

结论

借助这些最佳实践指南，设计人员和开发人员将能够优化他们的故事以供移动设备使用，确保流畅且用户友好的体验

随着 SAP分析云的 2024 年第四季度(Q4)季度发布更新(QRC)​​，SAC移动设备iOS应用将对兼容的故事启用精简版查看器。该技术将​​显著降低在移动设备上打开故事时的运行内存消耗​​。

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA configuration for SAC pull of plan data
entry.content:
This post deals with the SAP S/4HANA app “Manage Financial Plan Data Jobs - for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration” (in the following referred to as “manage” app) where mandatory configuration settings for pulling plan data from SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) into SAP S/4HANA tables like ACDOCP or FINSSKF are defined. These configuration settings are prerequisite for the app “Schedule Financial Plan Data Jobs for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration“ to execute a financial plan data job (for data replication). The integration using these two apps is available in SAP S/4HANA Public and Private Cloud Edition.

The goal is to provide guidance on the necessary configuration settings in this manage app and show example configurations based on SAC content for different use cases.

It is recommended to bookmark this post, as we plan to enhance it with further recommendations and configuration settings.

Before creating a configuration, first in the manage app a tenant ID (with communication details) of a SAP Analytics Cloud tenant must be defined which is explained in the following online help:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/1cbcff7ccd35405ab445b223c1ab1588/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US
  • SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/48f4b4785b8e45938ac44a67be8032d9/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US

This post is based on the following SAC content for Integrated Financial Planning with possible plan data replications into S/4HANA tables but apply to other (customer specific) SAC models writing into these S/4HANA tables as well.

To simplify, we assume that depreciations are copied from the SAC model CAPEX to model OPEX and asset values ​​from the SAC model CAPEX to model Financial Statement Planning. So we only deal with configuration entries for plan data related to OPEX, Sales and Profitability Planning and Financial Statement. CO2 values ​​are also ignored (might be addressed in a later version of this post).

We start with functional and technical basics, continue with general recommendations and finally show some example configurations.

Functional Basics

For replication of plan data related to the three IFP models OPEX, Profitability and Financial Statement into SAP S/4HANA, the following SAC modeling details must be considered:

  • In contrast to Profitability and Financial Statement, only OPEX has a dimension for the debit/credit indicator to represent cost charges and discharges. However, for profitability and financial statement data, the debit/credit indicator ‘D’ is added by default when writing into table ACDOCP. The debit/credit indicator becomes part of the plan data scope explained below.
  • When transferring sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability, the same account used to post into Profitability is used to credit records in OPEX. However, in contrast to OPEX, product and plant information is added to these costs in Profitability.
  • The starting point for financial statement planning is a copy of actual data from the previous year’s financial statement. Then plan data from OPEX and Profitability are copied into Financial Statement, i.e. these copy processes do NOT result in corresponding credit records on the sender side.
  • The IFP content in SAC offers two possible sources for bringing a profit and loss statement into table ACDOCP:
    • Option 1: The model Financial Statement serves as the source to ensure a complete P&L statement. Since the copy of actual data is used as a starting point, the data can contain recurring extraordinary revenues and costs like the dissolution of accruals etc. 
    • Option 2: The two models OPEX and Profitability serve as the source. Here special attention is required for the account(s) used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability (more on this later). In contrast to Option 1, this option has only operating costs and revenues.

Technical Basics

It is important to understand that contrary to table ACDOCA, table ACDOCP represents a multidimensional view. Therefore, the key fields of table ACDOCP consist of purely technical fields. This makes it necessary to specify a so-called aggregation level and plan data scope when writing data into table ACDOCP. These are explained below (among other technical terms for the Manage app).

  1. Aggregation level
    The aggregation level determines the fields of the records for which plan data is transferred into SAP S/4HANA. In the following mapping view of the configuration for the SAC plan data pull, the listed SAP S/4HANA fields are automatically translated into this aggregation level:
    As you can see in the last four columns of the screenshot above, it does not matter for the derivation of the aggregation level whether the field is mapped 1:1 from SAC, derived from an attribute (of an SAC dimension), or defined as a fixed value.
  2. Plan Data Scope
    The plan data scope influences which existing data records in table ACDOCP are replaced by the new plan data. Therefore, based on the fields marked “In Scope” (i.e. plan data scope) and their corresponding values from the plan data (to be written into ACDOCP), a data set is identified in the (multidimensional) table ACDOCP.
    It is important to understand that for the derivation of this “data set” not only the existing value combinations from the fields marked as “In Scope” are used, but also cross-combinations of these field values (see example 3 below).
    The following three scenarios show how new plan data with the respective plan data scope setting overwrites existing data in table ACDOCP.

    The more fields are added to the plan data scope, the fewer existing records can be overwritten with the new data, and thus the impacted data section is smaller (see example 2). This is also the reason why some fields such as the planning category or time-related fields like LedgerFiscalYear or FiscalYearPeriod are mandatory in the plan data scope, so that more data than desired is not accidentally overwritten when writing plan data into ACDOCP.
    In the configuration of the manage application, the plan data scope is defined in following highlighted column of the mapping view.
  3. Interaction between update mode and plan data scope
    Because the update mode for reading the relevant plan data records in SAC is a full update, SAC data is always written as a “whole” into table ACDOCP. Therefore, for cost-center-related costs, for example, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope (to replace the existing cost-center-related accounts and periods with the new plan data). Another example are project-related costs, where the WBSElement, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope. This ensures that the new plan data from SAC replaces the existing data in ACDOCP correctly.
  4. Account selection
    In the Filter Settings section of a configuration ID in the Manage app, meaningful data selections via G/L accounts are limited, as hierarchy nodes are not supported for the account field. For example, selecting primary accounts, cost accounts or balance sheet accounts using hierarchy nodes is not supported. Unfortunately, this type of selection is only possible via flat account selection, where the relevant accounts are then listed.
  5. Lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP
    Given that the lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP is based on the SAP S/4HANA fields PlanningCategory, ControllingArea, CompanyCode and LedgerFiscalYear, simultaneously running pull jobs into the same planning category can lock each other (for overlapping controlling areas, company code and fiscal year). However, in SAP S/4HANA no locks can occur if simultaneous pull jobs are writing into different planning categories. Therefore this should be considered when using multiple configuration IDs.

General configuration-specific recommendations

After clarifying some functional and technical basics, let’s look at the following recommendations for the configuration:

  • In general, overlapping plan data across different configurations which are written into the same planning category inevitably leads to inconsistent data when running the financial plan data jobs for the respective configuration IDs (due to the conflict with the plan data scope and subsequent mutual overwriting). An example of this is the configuration for (total) expenses and another configuration specifically for project-related expenses (subset of total expenses). Therefore, it is important to avoid such cases by defining different plan categories in the mapping section for the SAP S/4HANA field PlanningCategory.
  • Plan data from the IFP model Financial Statement must always kept in a separate planning category (in contrast to plan data from the IFP models OPEX and Sales & Profitability) to avoid inconsistencies due to duplicate figures. The reason is that OPEX und Sales & Profitability data is copied into the SAC model Financial Statement without crediting on the sender side.
  • In the case of writing OPEX and Profitability data into one planning category (for an alternative P&L report in SAP S/4HANA), having the field GLAccount as an additional “In Scope” field helps differentiate the two data sets (to avoid mutual overwrite), if OPEX and Sales & Profitability use different GL accounts. However, if, for example, a single GL account is used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Sales and Profitability, this approach no longer ensures disjoint data, and the plan data scope must be expanded. If, as shown in the following example, OPEX consists only of cost center data (and is marked as “In Scope”), and all Sales & Profitability data has a Plant, Sold Material and Customer allocation (and is marked as “In Scope”), disjoint data is ensured as well (without mutual overwrite):
  • A mapping of profit center and functional area values for a given configuration ID in the view ”Mapping of Financial Plan Data” ​​(to transfer both fields from SAC) is optional for OPEX and Profitability, since both would be automatically derived in the ACDOCP write interface if missing. If, however, Profit Center and Functional Area are mapped (and thus transferred from SAC), the correct profit center and functional area assignment is checked in SAP S/4HANA before writing plan data into table ACDOCP.  If this consistency check fails because, for example, the derived account assignment type returns a different profit center, an error message appears and the data transfer is aborted. Therefore, when mapping the functional area and/or profit center, ensure that the master data in SAP Analytics Cloud is up to date.
  • When using the SAP-delivered planning categories BUDGET01, BUDGET02 and BUDGET03 when writing into table ACDOCP,  the following default value for Budget Consistency Check (screenshot taken from SSCUI ID 102822) requires that additional (plan data scope) requirements be taken into account:For example, for project budget (planning category BUDGET01), plan data scope must NOT be active for WBSElement, FiscalPeriod, FiscalYearPeriod and CompanyCode. For the cost center budget (planning category BUDGET02), plan data scope must NOT be active for FiscalPeriod and FiscalYearPeriod.
  • Balance sheet data as part of financial statement planning requires a balance carry-forward logic to ensure that opening balance and balance sheet movements within a fiscal year are correctly replicated from SAC into table ACDOCP. Like in the SAC Export API, this requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA global field BalanceFlowType (see in below file configuration ID 30001).
  • Costs split into fixed and variable costs in SAC can also be replicated and stored in table ACDOCP, which requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA field FixedVariableType. In this case, the data records split into fixed and variable are merged into one data record on the SAP S/4HANA side, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written into the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).

Example Configurations

Finally, the file in the following URL shows predefined configuration settings to give an idea of how to configure specific content in the mapping and filter section: https://d.dam.sap.com/a/MVuKTRq?rc=10&doi=SAP1225684

The first example (configuration ID 10001) from the file for OPEX-related plan data on cost centers and projects, including value-based allocations, is explained based on screenshots from the manage app:

Mapping of Financial Plan Data

  • For the SAC measure AMOUNT on the SAP S/4HANA side, the measure AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency is used (and the currency derived from a property of the company code), assuming the company code currency in SAC plan data.
  • The displayed plan data scope contains the mandatory plan data scope fields PlanningCategory, CompanyCode and FiscalYearPeriod (or LedgerFiscalYear) and is sufficient if there is no other overlapping configuration ID writing into the same planning category.
  • As described, ProfitCenter and FunctionalArea are not included, as this proposal relies on the derivation rules in SAP S/4HANA to derive the two fields in the background when writing plan data into table ACDOCP.
  • Including the source field FixedVariableType ensures that when writing into table ACDOCP the plan data is reformatted accordingly, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written to the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).
  • In the example, the SAP Planning category PLN is used. Likewise, another category can be selected, which is maintained in SAP S/4HANA with Application Type “Periodic Planning & Consolidation” and Category Usage “NO specific usage” (in SSCUI 101970, Maintain Category for Planning).

Filter Settings for Financial Plan Data

  • The mandatory single value filter for the source field Version is maintained here. In the IFP content, the version Plan is used by default and may need to be adjusted if it differs in the custom data model.
  • It should also be filtered by planning period to select the plan data to the respective planning year.
  • In this example, further filter settings are not necessary because, on the one hand, this configuration is for OPEX-related plan data including cost centers and projects and only the AMOUNT measure is mapped. Other measures are excluded (like measures related to allocation weights ).

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Performance Recommendations for Story Designers
entry.content:
Starting with 2025.Q3 QRC Release and Wave 2025.13 we release Performance Recommendations in the Info Panel of the Story Design Time in SAP Analytics Cloud

How can story developers ensure that their content not only captivates visually but also performs optimally? In our latest update, available in Wave 13 2025 or with the Q3 QRC, we reveal how the info panel now provides crucial insights into the widgets that influence content performance during the design phase. This enhancement builds upon our existing widget in-app analysis, allowing you to proactively identify areas for improvement and close performance gaps, helping your stories to be both engaging and effective.

Evolution of the in-app widget analysis

The in-app widget analysis was the first step in the journey of our guided design approach. Previously, developers had to individually check each widget to determine whether performance recommendations were available. This could be a time-consuming process, especially depending on the complexity of the story. To streamline this experience, we now present this information consolidated for the entire page. This enhancement allows developers to quickly assess performance issues and focus their efforts on optimizing content more efficiently.

Guide to Using the Info Panel for Performance Recommendations

Step 1: Open the Info Panel

After opening your Story in edit mode, click the “Info Panel” icon in the upper right corner of the user interface. You can recognize it by the red dot, indicating that recommendations are available.

Step 2: Overview of Performance Recommendations

In the Info Panel, you'll find various tabs. Select the “Performance Recommendations” tab to get an overview of the performance data and recommendations for the widgets in your story.

 

Step 3: View Detailed Recommendations

Under the “Performance Recommendations” tab, you will see a list of widgets that have performance issues. Each widget shows specific warnings marked with a red or yellow dot:

  • Red Dot: Indicates serious performance issues that should be addressed immediately. For example: “The initial drill level... is large. Decrease the drill level.”
  • Yellow Dot: Indicates potential issues that should be noted. For example: “The member 'Calculated Revenue' has 3 exception aggregation dimensions... Reduce the number of dimensions...”

 

Step 4: Take Action

Use the provided recommendations to take steps to optimize the performance issues. You can adjust drill levels, reduce the number of dimensions, or make other suggested changes. Be sure to check the performance again afterward.

Step 5: Continuous Performance Monitoring

Regularly check the “Performance Recommendations” tab to ensure your adjustments achieve the desired results. Use the Info Panel as an ongoing tool for optimizing your widgets and stories.

Summary

With the introduction of the new info panel for in-app widget analysis, we aim to foster a proactive approach to content design. Our goal is for designers to create high-performing content from the beginning, minimizing the risk of encountering performance issues that could have been identified and addressed during the design phase. The consolidated view of performance indicators and recommendations in the info panel empowers developers to make informed decisions and optimize their stories effectively. This not only enhances the efficiency of the development process but also improves the overall quality of the content produced.

Looking Ahead

As we continue to enhance the Info Panel, we want to keep you informed about our commitment to improving the performance notifications. Our team is actively working on refining the alerts and providing additional context to make the insights more actionable and valuable for your work.

In the coming releases, you can expect to see enriched information integrated into the performance recommendations. These updates will aim to provide clearer guidance and more specific actions to optimize your widgets effectively.

We encourage you to stay tuned and keep an eye on the updates in the Info Panel. Engaging with these enhancements will ensure that you are making the most of the tools available to you.

Thank you for being a part of this journey, and we look forward to supporting you with these improvements!

entry.title: The Next Phase in the Deprecation of the Classic Experience in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
As mentioned in the External Blog Post Important Notice: Changes in SAP Analytics Cloud Classic Stories & Analytic Applications, SAP Analytics Cloud has been in a phased approached to transition customers to the Optimized Experience.

With the 2025 Q3 QRC, SAP Analytics Cloud is entering its next phase. It reinforces our commitment to delivering a modern, high-performance, and consistent user experience within Business Data Cloud (BDC).

What’s Changing?

With this phase, customers will no longer be able to create new Classic Stories or Analytic Applications. For example, clicking on a new Canvas or Responsive Page in the Stories Module will now automatically launch the Optimized Story Experience instead of prompting the Designer in choosing between Optimized Story Experience and Classic Story Experience. It ensures that all new content benefits from the performance, usability, and functional improvements available.

  • 🔒 Creation of New Classic Stories and Applications is now DISABLED
  • ✅ Existing Classic Assets (Stories and Analytic Application) remain EDITABLE and FULLY MAINTAINABLE

Continued Access to Existing Classic Assets

Even though new content creation in classic is disabled, existing Classic Stories and Analytic Applications can still be maintained. Our definition of maintainable includes:

  • View, Edit, and Save Content
  • Share, Duplicate, and Delete

⚠️ Continued access to Classic Assets remains until the full deprecation in the 2026 Q2 QRC where these assets will no longer be accessible. It means that customers should begin the migration to the Optimized Experience prior to this date.

Enhancements to File Repository and Object Management

With this phase, we’ve made several usability improvements in how assets are presented and managed:

  • Visual Distinction: The File Repository now provides a clear visual distinction between Classic and Optimized Stories as well as Analytical Applications
  • (Deprecated) Labeling: Deprecated object types now include a “(Deprecated)” suffix in their type
  • Granular Filtering: Object Type Filtering now has more granularity to filter between Classic Stories (Deprecated), Analytical Applications (Deprecated), and Stories

 

Streamlining the User Interface

We’ve taken additional steps to simplify the user experience by removing entry points that led to these deprecated assets. For example:

  • Analytic Applications module no longer has a create button. It still displays the most recent Analytic Applications.
  • Stories module no longer has Smart Discovery or Grid Pages as selectable tiles
  • Clicking Canvas, Responsive, or Template now opens the Optimized Story instead of prompting the Designer in choosing between Optimized Story Experience and Classic Story Experience
  • Modeller module no longer has a Point of Interest Tab to create new Point of Interests
  • Actions from a Model to Create a new Canvas or Responsive opens the Optimized Story

 

Increasing Awareness for the Designer

Within the Classic Experience (Stories and Analytic Applications), we’ve increased the severity of our Deprecation Warning to a Deprecation Notice. It appears in a more prominent indicator reminding the Designer that the Classic Asset will be disabled starting mid-2026. This warning is only shown to Story Designers, the users best positioned to initiate migration.

 

Preparing for Full Deprecation in 2026

This phase marks a significant milestone in our journey toward unifying and modernizing the SAP Analytics Cloud experience. We encourage all customers to begin or continue transitioning their Classic Stories and Analytic Applications to the Optimized Experience before the 2026 Q2 QRC to avoid any disruption. There are a few resources that we recommend.

Mass Migration Tool

With the 2024 Q4 QRC, we had released a Mass Migration Tool for Designers to migrate up to 50 assets to the Optimized Experience. There are a few steps that are involved which includes:                                              

  1. Selection of Assets
  2. Conversion Check & Status
  3. Conversion Settings
  4. Conversion Summary

You can learn more in the External Blog Post, Bulk Migration Tool to Convert Classic Assets to the Optimized Experience

Mass Deletion Tool for System Admins

With the 2025 Q2 QRC, within the System Overview – Housekeeping, we had introduced an option for System Administers to delete specific objects, without the need of manual deletion object by object. There is a Last Access Date which helps System Administrators understand which objects are not actively used. 

But it doesn’t stop there. In addition to the primary object, all dependent objects are also automatically deleted. It means you no longer need to worry about unnecessary and unused objects adding up in your system and slowing down its performance.

You can learn more in the External Blog Post, Efficient Data Maintenance in SAP Analytics Cloud System Overview - Housekeeping

⚠️ For Stories we do not support the distinction between Classic and Optimized Experience. It will be made available in a future release.

entry.title: Building Stories That Other Developers Actually Want to Inherit
entry.content:
As SAC developers, we primarily focus on end-user requirements and experience, while also considering the broader impact of the content we build (network and source system performance).

But how often have you revisited an SAC story to enhance it, or inherited one created by someone else only to be confronted with a myriad of widgets using default names, no logical grouping, and layouts that require painful dragging and dropping to adjust?
In this blog, we’ll look at best practices based on experience that will make your life, and the lives of your fellow SAC developers far easier.

Naming Conventions
If you’ve read this far and get no further, the biggest single thing you can do to make developing SAC content easier is to use naming conventions.

  • Create a set of standard naming conventions for widgets
  • Give widgets meaningful names
  • Don’t get lazy and stop doing it

Below is an example of the prefixes I use, the main point being use something that works for you and your colleagues.
* Ensure it’s included in your organisation’s design guidelines

Widget Type

Standard Pre-Fix

Example

Bar Chart

chartB_

chartB_revenue_by_state

Line Chart

chartL_

chartL_margin_by_product

Numeric Point Chart

kpi_

kpi_actuals_vs_budget

Waterfall Chart

chartWF_

chartWF_spend

Table

tbl_

tbl_invoices_by_month

Panel

pnl_

pnl_title

Text Box

txt_

txt_title

Image

img_

img_logo

Shape

shape_

shape_header_divider

Button

btn_

btn_page2

Dropdown List

ddl_

ddl_product

List Box

lb_

lb_store

Radio Button Group

rbg_

rbg_managers

No one wants to see this in the outline view when editing a story!

When writing script it’s really not helpful hitting CTRL space and getting a meaningless list of charts……err which one was it again??

Far nicer to be presented with this.

Layouts
When building a story, I use panels wherever possible to group content.
Based on 100’s of story builds over the years I’ve yet to see a significant performance impact of using many panels within a SAC story.

Grouping content allows you to quickly navigate to it in design mode, makes it super easy to move blocks of content around if the layout needs changing.
It also makes scripting far simpler when you need to show/hide content (just hide the panel, not all the widgets it contains individually)

Example
This is typically how I structure a story layout, each distinct block of content is contained within a panel, you can also see in the outline view that the content is logically ordered top to bottom and left to right.

The same logical order (and naming convention) is carried on within each panel

At a glance you should be able to understand what is what and where it is, without even seeing the widgets in the main story window.

 

Script structure and annotation

This topic has been written about, probably shortly after the first ever line of code or script was created 😊
Yet it’s incredibly rare I open a SAC Story created by someone else and find fully documented script.
Even rarer is to find script that is not only annotated at a line level but also contains a summary level comment.
Summary level annotation provides great insight into the logic, how the block of code fits into the overall design & interaction with other code blocks.

As a quick example, here’s part of the code I wrote for a noughts and crosses game in SAC

 

Here’s part of the same script with annotation and a summary.
Someone else picking up work on this story would quickly be able to understand the logic and how the code interacts with other script in the story.

In this example I simply pasted the code into Chat GPT and asked it to annotate and summarise the script.
It did a fairly decent job, but you should always sanity check the output.

Other Thoughts

Panel Auto Scroll
I always turn this off, no one needs yet more scroll bars!
plus it makes it harder to arrange content within panels if there’s no hard stop on the widget layout position.

Flow Panels
Awful things 😊 they make setting up layouts really painful and shouldn’t be needed if you’re clear about what you’re building.

Dynamic Layout / Sizing
It’s always a challenge to build a story that looks good on varying screen sizes.
I typically build the story using auto widget widths and fixed px left and right values, once I’m happy with the overall layout I change the Left/Right px unit to %
This allows widgets to auto size better when screen sizes vary.
You can go a step further and setup a number of CSS styles to change font sizes etc when the widget size changes.

Summary
Taking the time to apply consistent naming conventions, logical layouts, and well-structured, annotated scripting is about building SAC stories that are scalable, maintainable, and developer friendly.
Whether you're handing a project over to a colleague or revisiting it six months later, these habits dramatically reduce friction and improve development efficiency.

Good design isn’t just for end users, it starts with the developer.

entry.title: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @Nektarios_Vasileiou33 and @BlazZabukovec .

Picture 1: SAP Analytics Cloud demo story example - Dashboard design by Daniel Davis

Motivation

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering (THIS BLOG POST)

  2. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?

  3. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world

  4. Planning & Analysis in the context of SAP BDC

  5. Move BPC and BW-IP into SAP BDC

  6. Real-time steering with LIVE planning

  7. PaPM use cases

  8. Self – service analytics and real time business steering

  9. Business steering powered by AI agents

  10. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting

  11. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

CHALLENGES

The current global market situation is characterised by heightened volatility and uncertainty, driven by factors such as geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures and rapid technological advancements. In this dynamic environment businesses face significant challenges like supply chain disruptions, rising and uncontrolled operational costs and the need for digital transformation to remain competitive.

Obviously, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to every challenge, but adopting a data-driven decision-making process provides significant advantages that can help organizations navigate complexities and respond more effectively to market dynamics. By relying on data to drive decisions, businesses can achieve greater accuracy and insight, which helps in identifying trends, understanding customer behaviours, and optimising operations. This approach enables companies to be more agile and responsive to changing conditions.

Every leader today feels the weight of growing complexity. CFOs balancing growth and profitability. CHROs managing talent in an evolving workforce. CIOs modernising IT while keeping innovation alive.

Picture 2: Challenges by CXO persona

But the true challenge lies in how these functions are increasingly interconnected. When one part of the business is disrupted, whether it’s a supply chain issue or a talent gap, the ripple effects are felt everywhere. To succeed, businesses need more than solutions for individual challenges, businesses need a way to align every function and unlock collective power.

Like Aristotle (apparently) once said: “THE WHOLE IS GREATER THAN THE SUM OF ITS PARTS”

Today’s complexity demands more than incremental fixes and silo apps/solutions. If we want to have benefits from AI and systems of agents collaborating across all functions, we need to have a solid foundation, where we can seamlessly combine applications, data, insights and AI into one ecosystem.

Just picture this example around Financial Planning (incl. forecasting & simulation), where we can develop a comprehensive financial snapshot while automating workflow tasks through agentic AI.

Picture 3: Forecasting & Simulation use case evolution

This is where we bring together all relevant data, like revenues, expenses, also across different scenarios, like actuals, plan & forecast. We also integrate all relevant external data, like different macro-economic KPIs, external market research data., etc. Based on identified key drivers/influencers of our business, we are going to define and perform different planning/forecasting scenarios. In the next step we are going to simulate and analyse impact of external drivers like inflation rate on our performance and identify the areas that will be impacted. Specialised analytics agent can propose potential mitigation strategies, like targeted promotions to drive customer demand, that can be further assessed & analysed. Based on this information we can decide for a certain course of actions that can be triggered by system of agents.

Picture 4: Risk analysis & mitigation strategies delivered by agentic AI

We can say with great confidence that our customers are not working in the area of visualising their data and that’s why SAP is also not in the business of visualising our customer’s data (even though we can do this is in a great way), but we are in a business of enabling the “Insights to Action” framework which is exactly what I have illustrated in the use case around financial planning powered by agentic AI.

Organizations striving to make data-driven decisions and a proper, also AI powered jump from insights to action, encounter several significant challenges. One major obstacle is seamlessly integrating data across various systems to extract valuable business insights. Additionally, ensuring data quality and integrity is crucial to maintaining trust in the decision-making process. Furthermore, building a comprehensive data foundation is essential for supporting the deployment of AI-based applications. Addressing these challenges requires robust data management strategies and innovative solutions to harness the full potential of data for valuable decision-making.

SAP's STRATEGY

To tackle these challenges, SAP developed the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to provide cloud services that empower organizations in navigating the complexities of data management and business steering process. SAP BDC serves as a unified platform, providing the necessary agility for effective business steering. SAP BDC offers a semantically rich, unified data environment that enhances operational efficiency and strategic decision-making capabilities. By centralising key business data from SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer, SAP BDC unlocks insights, advanced analytics, and AI capabilities, empowering businesses to drive intelligent growth and innovation.

Picture 5: SAP Business Suite

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a fully managed Software as a Service (SaaS) solution that unifies and governs all SAP data while seamlessly connecting with third-party data. The solution combines the capabilities of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse, along with managed SAP Databricks. SAP BDC includes curated business-ready data products from SAP line of business applications leveraged by business-ready Intelligent Applications providing line-of-business leaders the context needed to make impactful decisions.

Picture 6: High level overview of SAP BDC services

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud:

SAP Datasphere: As the foundational element of SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere provides a streamlined environment for data integration, warehousing, and governance. It features flexible integrated data tiering—comprising object, disk-based, and in-memory storage—ensuring a cost-effective persistence layer. Additionally, it offers sophisticated tools for analytical data modeling, transformation, and integration, enabling organizations to extract valuable insights and foster business innovation. Users can also utilize the framework to develop their own data products.

SAP Analytics Cloud: This component delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience.

SAP Databricks: Through SAP's partnership with Databricks, data science capabilities are significantly enhanced. This collaboration facilitates advanced analytics and data science operations on both SAP and non-SAP data. Key features include ML Flows for machine learning operations, Mosaic AI for model training and serving, and Notebooks equipped with coding assistants and visualizations. The serverless Spark offerings aim to simplify big data processing, while replication-free access to SAP data products and integration with the Unity Catalogue further enrich the experience.

Intelligent Applications and Data Products: SAP Business Data Cloud emphasizes Intelligent Applications and SAP-managed Data Products. These ready-to-use, standardized business data objects and applications are managed by SAP, reducing the effort needed to build and operate analytical and data science applications. They promote data consistency and reusability, serving as modular, reusable assets for analytical models or AI/ML and planning workflows.

Unified Semantic Layer: Central to SAP Business Data Cloud is the unified semantic model, which standardizes data definitions across SAP and non-SAP systems. It offers simplified zero-copy data access via a standardized delta-share interface, supporting cross-domain analytics and AI applications. Additionally, it features a centralized cross-application catalog for data products and Intelligent Applications.

SAP BW: is integrated into SAP BDC, allowing SAP BW objects to be onboarded as data products. The SAP BW data products can be integrated in SAP Databricks to enable advanced analytics and data science use cases.

BUSINESS VALUE

SAP BDC delivers significant business value in the context of business steering, particularly within planning and analytics use cases. 

Enhanced Decision-Making: SAP BDC revolutionises decision-making by providing real-time access to integrated data. This SAP Analytics Cloud capability ensures that business leaders receive accurate and immediate insights, empowering them to make informed and strategic decisions. With this enhanced decision-making capacity, organizations can effectively anticipate market trends, adjust their strategies in response to evolving conditions, and maintain a competitive edge in their respective industries.

Comprehensive Data Integration: At the heart of SAP BDC is its ability to seamlessly integrate data from multiple sources, both SAP and non-SAP systems. This integration creates a unified view of the organisation's data landscape, supporting precise planning and predictive forecasting. By breaking down data silos and ensuring a holistic perspective, SAP BDC enables businesses to gain comprehensive insights into their operations and make well-rounded decisions. The data holistic perspective is fundamental for organizations to unleash AI across the entire data ecosystem.

Scalable Analytics and Planning Capabilities: One of the standout features of SAP BDC is its scalable analytics and planning capabilities. It allows businesses to conduct extensive analyses and simulations, uncovering valuable insights that aid in tailoring forecasts to specific scenarios. Whether it's understanding customer behavior or predicting market shifts, SAP Analytics Cloud robust analytics and planning capabilities in combination with SAP Databricks empower organizations to make data-driven predictions with unmatched precision and confidence.

Improved Efficiency and Agility: SAP BDC streamlines data integration and analytics processes, significantly enhancing efficiency and agility within organizations. By automating these crucial processes, leveraging data management features in SAP Datasphere, analytics in SAP Analytics Cloud and AI/ML workflows in SAP Databricks, it cuts down the time and effort needed for data preparation and analysis (replication free access of data and zero-copy). This efficiency allows teams to redirect their focus from operational concerns to strategic steering, driving more meaningful business results in less time.

Facilitated Innovation: Leveraging cutting-edge technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, SAP BDC promotes innovation within organizations. Its cloud-based infrastructure ensures that businesses have access to the latest advancements, encouraging the exploration of new and innovative business models. This focus on facilitated innovation helps companies remain at the forefront of industry trends and continuously evolve their offerings.

Consistency in Data Governance: Ensuring data integrity and consistency is a critical component of SAP BDC's value proposition. The platform offers comprehensive data governance and quality management, providing reliable data integrity across planning and analytics activities. With consistent data definitions and governance, businesses can achieve accurate reporting and foster alignment across various departments, leading to cohesive planning strategies.

Seamless Collaboration: SAP BDC enhances collaboration by centralising data accessibility and sharing. Data Cataloguing, Data Sharing and Collaboration capabilities foster improved teamwork among departments and enables synchronised planning efforts and a guided steering process. With shared insights and aligned goals, teams can work together more effectively, driving unified strategies and achieving common objectives that benefit the entire organisation.

Strategic Resource Allocation: Through its predictive analytics and planning capabilities SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Databricks, SAP BDC enables organizations to allocate resources more strategically. By delivering actionable insights, businesses can optimize operations, improve resource allocation, and enhance overall performance. This strategic approach ensures that resources are used efficiently to achieve maximum impact, driving profound business success.

Future-Proofing Autonomous Business Steering: By harnessing SAP AI agents within the trusted SAP BDC data foundation, the planning and business steering process is transformed from a static, periodic exercise into a dynamic, proactive function. These AI-driven insights empower companies to swiftly assess the potential impacts of various strategic options and make decisive actions. This approach allows businesses to anticipate market changes and respond efficiently, making strategic adjustments with confidence and precision.

CONCLUSION

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) stands as a vital tool for organisations striving to enhance their decision-making capabilities, align strategic objectives, and navigate the complexities of modern business landscapes. In the era of AI, organizations require scalable and efficient data architectures to manage growing volumes of data and extract actionable insights leveraging advanced analytics, planning and machine learning capabilities. As we embark on this informative blog series, we invite you to stay tuned for our upcoming posts, where we will delve deeper into the AI, Planning & Analytics functionalities associated with SAP BDC and business steering use cases. Gain insights into how this powerful platform can drive your business forward, optimise operations, and help you achieve your strategic goals with confidence. Join us in exploring the transformative potential of SAP BDC and discover how it can be the catalyst for your organisation's growth and success.

CALL TO ACTION

entry.title: はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - スマートインサイト
entry.content:
本ブログシリーズはSAP Analytics CloudのBI機能をつかってダッシュボードやレポートの作成を行う方を対象とし、SAP Analytics CloudのBIにおける基本の操作やTipsをハンズオン形式でご紹介します。

本ブログでは、「ストーリーを見ている時にグラフに表示されていない分析軸を含めたより詳細な情報や差異の要因を知りたい」際に統計分析を使用してシステムが分析結果を自動的に提供してくれる機能である、スマートインサイトについてご紹介いたします。

※2025Q2アップデートで最適化ストーリーエクスペリエンスでもスマートインサイトが利用可能になりました。

 

目次：

  • スマートインサイトの概要
  • スマートインサイトの利用方法[ハンズオン]
    • スマートインサイトを利用した分析
    • スマートインサイトの分析結果をもとにストーリーを作成

※ベースとなるサンプルストーリーの作成⼿順は、はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityでご紹介しています。
※ SAP Analytics Cloudは、四半期に１度のペースで製品のバージョンアップが実施されます。そのため今後のバージョンアップにより、本ブログで紹介する画⾯キャプチャや、操作が異なる可能性があることをご了承ください。（本ブログは2025年8⽉に作成しています。）

 

スマートインサイトの概要

SAP Analytics Cloudのスマートインサイト機能は、ストーリーのチャートに表示されていない要因分析をシステムを使って自動化することで、分析を深めたい部分に関してのチャートを追加で作成することなく、ユーザーがストーリー上で即座に分析を行うことに役立ちます。ユーザーがストーリーを利用して分析していたり会議でストーリーを利用していて「ある製品の売上高が高くなっている要因を知りたい」「差異の原因を知りたい」といった際に便利です。

また、スマートインサイトはストーリーの編集モードで利用することで分析結果のチャートをストーリー作成に再利用できます。分析結果をそのままストーリーに追加することでストーリー作成を効率化したり、SAP Analytics Cloudの操作に慣れていないユーザーのストーリー作成の補助としても利用することができます。

詳しくはHelp Portalもご参照ください：スマートインサイト

スマートインサイトの利用方法

0. はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityで作成したストーリーを開こう！

 

1. スマートインサイトを使って分析しよう！

1.1. 分析したいチャートまたはデータポイントを右クリックし、メニューから「スマートインサイト」を選択します。

1.2. 画面右側にスマートインサイトパネルが表示されます。

1.3. スマートインサイトパネルで、データポイントが時間の経過とともに変化してきた状況やデータポイントへの主要なコントリビュータ、データポイントの計算方法を確認することができます。

（参考）グラフに差異が表示されている場合は、差異に対してスマートインサイトを実行し分析を行うことができます。

 

2. スマートインサイトを使ってストーリーを作成しよう！

2.1. 「編集」をクリックし、ストーリー編集モードに切り替えます。

2.2. 分析したいチャートまたはデータポイントを右クリックし、メニューから「スマートインサイト」を選択します。

2.3. 画面右側のスマートインサイトパネルの利用したいチャートから「コピー」ボタンをクリックし、「コピー」を選択します。

2.4. 「Ctrl＋V」またはメニューバーから「コピー」→「ペースト」を選択し、チャートを貼り付けます。

 必要に応じて貼り付けたチャートを編集したり、サイズを変えることなども可能です。

 

今回はスマートインサイト 機能のご紹介でした。SAP Analytics Cloudは他にも様々な表現や便利な機能があり、本ブログシリーズでご紹介しています。はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - シリーズまとめ - SAP Communityからご参照ください。

Hello and welcome! In this blog, I'm excited to share the progress I've made on creating easy-to-use dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) using data from SAP Cloud ALM (CALM) Health Monitoring (HM) and Real User Monitoring (RUM). entry.title: CSS in SAC - Borders & Shadows a quick guide to css syntax
entry.content:
This blog post provides a quick run through of the various border and shadow effects you can apply with CSS in SAC,
the examples given are based on the panel widget.

SAC CSS Engine
In SAC, the CSS engine expects explicitly defined styles, especially for compound shorthand properties like border, border-top, etc.
SAC requires all 3 properties to be set e.g. for a border:     border: [width] [style] [color];
e.g.

Outer & Inner CSS Classes
When you open the CSS menu and select any Widget from the dropdown menu, SAC will always show
the ‘Widget CSS Class’ options.
This is the outer class for the widget, below this you will then see the widget specific inner class.

Outer class

Widget specific inner class (button in this example)

 

Styles
The CSS help / example for each Widget type doesn’t specify supported styles
e.g. For a panel widget it simply lists the supported classes – background-color, border etc.

 

It takes a bit of trial and error to find which styles work for each class & widget combination.
e.g. for borders:

Undocumented Style Parameters:
border: double
border: groove
border: ridge
border: solid
border: dashed
border: dotted

Colours

When assigning colours via a CSS class we can use
RGB                                   - Red, Green, Blue
RGBA                                 - Red, Green, Blue, Alpha (opacity)
HEX                                    - Hexadecimal
Basic Colour typed       - red , blue , orange etc.

RGB  or HEX is used when we only want to apply a solid colour e.g.
Red
rgb: 255,0,0     /     hex: #FF0000

RGB 
Each parameter (red, green, and blue) defines the intensity of the color between 0 and 255.
For example, rgb(255, 0, 0) is displayed as red, because red is set to its highest value (255) and the others are set to 0.

To display black, set all color parameters to 0, like this: rgb(0, 0, 0).
To display white, set all color parameters to 255, like this: rgb(255, 255, 255).

RGBA
Is used when we want to define colour & opacity, the Alpha (A) value can be between 0 &1
e.g.  rgba(255,0,0,0.2) sets the opacity to 20% 

Borders

Documented Properties:  (listed in the SAC CSS menu)
border, border-top, border-right, border-bottom, border-left, opacity
*        Descendants: N/A;
*        Pseudos: N/A;

Undocumented Style Parameters:
border: double
border: groove
border: ridge
border: solid
border: dashed
border: dotted

Border Examples

Solid border

.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }
/* Solid black border, 6px wide all-round the widget

Applies a solid border to a widget 

Top Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-top: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }         

Bottom Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-bottom: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }

Left Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-left: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }

Right Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-right: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }

 

Double lined border
Applies a double border to a widget.                                                     
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 6px double rgba(34, 54, 73, 0.5);  }

Groove border
Applies a groove style border to a widget.
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px groove rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }          

Ridge border
Applies a ridge style border to a widget.                                                     
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px ridge rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }

Dotted border
Applies a dotted style border to a widget.    
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px dotted rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }                                             

Dashed border
Applies a dashed style border to a widget.    
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px dashed rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }                                        


Multi coloured borders
Applies colour to top and bottom 20px wide borders.   
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget {
    border-top:    20px solid rgba(255, 201, 51, 0.9);
    border-bottom: 20px solid red;   }         

Apply multiple border styles in a CSS class
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
border-top:4px solid #FFC933;
border-right: 4px dashed #CCC;
border-bottom: 4px dotted rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);
border-left: 4px solid rgb(100, 100, 255);      }


Note how we are able to mix and match border styles, we can also interchangeably use RGB , RGBA & HEX for the colour coding.

 

Shadow
Documented Properties:  (listed in the SAC CSS menu)
box-shadow
*        Descendants: N/A;
*        Pseudos: N/A;
Undocumented Properties:
inset

Box Shadow
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget { box-shadow: 5px 5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }

Explanation
box-shadow adds a shadow effect around the element’s box.
5px 5px → the horizontal and vertical offset of the shadow.
10px → the blur radius (how soft or sharp the shadow is).
rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3) → the color of the shadow: black (0,0,0) with 30% transparency.

Have a play with the parameters, for example set the offset values to -5px   and the shadow will appear on the left and top of the widget.
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget { box-shadow: ---5px -5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }



Inset Box Shadow
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget { box-shadow: inset 5px 5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }

Stacked Inset Shadow
Combines inset shadow with an outer shadow, making the panel appear raised but with an inner depth.                
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget {
    box-shadow: inset 5px 5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3),
                                            8px 8px 15px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);  }

One-Sided Inset Shadow
Creates a shadow only on the left inner side of the panel.      
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget {
    box-shadow: inset 10px 0px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }

Multiple Shadows
Combines inset shadow with an outer shadow,
making the panel appear raised but with an inner depth.
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget { 
        box-shadow:
               inset 3px 3px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3),
               inset -3px -3px 8px rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.2); }                

Hard Edged Shadow
To create a solid, cut-out like effect, set the blur radius (third value) to 0px.    
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {    box-shadow: inset 5px 5px 0px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); }

Opacity – Box Shadow Combo
Set the panel opacity to 85% and apply a box shadow     
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {   
          opacity: 0.85;
          box-shadow: inset 0px 0px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);  }            

Glow Effect Shadow
Applies a coloured glow effect border to a panel.                                  
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
        box-shadow:
        0px 0px 15px rgba(0, 255, 255, 0.6);  }   /* Cyan glow */

entry.title: ChatGPT Meets SAP Analytics Cloud: A Developer’s Guide to ChatGPT Custom Widget
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is a powerful platform for data analytics, planning, and predictive insights. Enhancing SAC with AI-driven conversational capabilities can significantly improve user interaction and data exploration. The ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAC enables seamless integration of OpenAI's ChatGPT chat box directly into your SAC stories and analytic applications, providing a flexible, fast, and customizable chat interface. This blog walks you through the features, installation, and usage of the ChatGPT Custom Widget, empowering you to leverage AI-powered conversational analytics within SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

What is the ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAC?

The ChatGPT Custom Widget is a ready-to-use component that embeds a ChatGPT-powered chat box inside your SAC environment. It allows users to interact with data and analytics through natural language queries, enhancing the decision-making process with AI-generated insights.

📥Download Links: ChatGPT Custom Widget: https://sap-custom-widget.rohitchouhan.com/?dl=ChatGPT
🔗GitHub Repository: https://github.com/SAP-Custom-Widget/ChatGPT
📚Documentation: chatgpt-custom-widget-documentation.pdf 

Key Features and Capabilities:

  • 100% Free to Use (needs OpenAI API key)
  • Modern Chat Interface: WhatsApp/Messenger-style design
  • Multiple AI Models: GPT-3.5-turbo, GPT-4, GPT-4-turbo support
  • Advanced Parameters: Temperature (0-2), max tokens (1-4096), response choices (1-10)
  • Custom Styling: Colors, fonts, sizes, themes
  • Real-time Responses: Streaming text generation
  • Export Chat:  Conversation export
  • Error Handling: Built-in API error management
  • Auto-updates: Widget version notifications
  • Mobile Responsive: Works on tablets and phones

Installation Guide

Follow these simple steps to add the ChatGPT Custom Widget to your SAP Analytics Cloud environment:

  1. Download the Widget JSON File
    Obtain the ChatGPT.json file from the official GitHub repository or the provided link.
  2. Access SAC Custom Widgets
    Log in to your SAC portal. Navigate to Stories from the left sidebar, then select the Custom Widget tab.
  3. Upload the Widget
    Click the + icon on the right side and upload the downloaded ChatGPT.json file.
  4. Ready to Use
    The widget is now available for use in your SAC stories and analytic applications.

Complete Guidance and Tutorial Video

If you want to see how to use and install what are the feature, please follow this video to know it better.

Configuration and Usage

  1. Get OpenAI API Key
    Visit platform.openai.com → Sign up/Login → Go to API Keys → Create new key → Copy and save securely
  2. Add Widget to Story
    Open your SAC story → Insert → Custom Widget → Select "ChatGPT Widget" → Drag to canvas
  3. Configure API Settings
    Designer Panel → Builder → API Configuration:
    • API Key: Paste your OpenAI key
    • Model: Choose gpt-3.5-turbo (fast, cheap) or gpt-4 (better quality)
    • Temperature: 0.1 (focused) to 1.5 (creative)
    • Max Tokens: 150-2048 (response length)
    • System Message: Set AI behavior and context
  4. Customize Appearance
    Design tab →  Styles, header text
  5. Test and Deploy
    Preview mode → Test chat functionality → Save story → Share with users

Advanced Use Cases and Applications

Business Intelligence Applications:

  • Data Exploration: "Show me sales trends for Q4" or "What are the top performing products?"
  • Report Generation: Auto-create executive summaries from dashboard data
  • Anomaly Detection: Ask AI to identify unusual patterns in data
  • KPI Analysis: Get explanations for metric changes and recommendations

Industry-Specific Applications:

  • Customer Service: Automate FAQ responses, provide product recommendations, handle basic inquiries
  • Sales & Marketing: Lead qualification, campaign analysis, customer segmentation insights
  • Finance: Budget variance analysis, financial report explanations, cost optimization suggestions
  • Operations: Process optimization, resource allocation, performance monitoring
  • HR Analytics: Employee satisfaction analysis, recruitment insights, performance reviews

Integrating ChatGPT with SAC transforms your analytics environment into an interactive, AI-powered assistant that enhances productivity and decision-making.

Security Considerations:

  • API Key Protection: Never share or hardcode API keys
  • Data Privacy: Be cautious with sensitive business data in prompts
  • Rate Limiting: Monitor API usage to avoid quota limits
  • Access Control: Restrict widget access to authorized users only
  • Regular Updates: Keep widget updated for security patches

Conclusion

The ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAP Analytics Cloud is a game-changer for organizations looking to infuse AI-driven conversational intelligence into their analytics workflows. With easy installation, flexible customization, and powerful OpenAI integration, this widget empowers users to interact naturally with their data and unlock deeper insights.

Get started today by downloading the widget, setting up your OpenAI API key, and embedding the chat box into your SAC stories. Experience the future of analytics with ChatGPT and SAP Analytics Cloud!

If you want to explore the widget further or contribute, check out the GitHub repository maintained by the developer Rohit Chouhan.

entry.title: How to Design Low-Fidelity Dashboards with the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit
entry.content:
Focus of this blog:

  • Intro
  • How the library is set up
  • How to get the library
  • How to use the library
  • How to work efficiently with the library
  • Essential Ressources

 

Intro

Effective dashboard design begins with user research. Gathering and understanding the necessary insights of your end-users' needs and requirements ensures high-quality experience. Jumping straight into creating high-fidelity mockups or even building dashboards directly in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories can create unnecessary distraction and slow down your design process.

👉  Learn how to build better dashboards here.

Instead, start with scribbles and rough sketches. Early in the process, low-fidelity mockups help you explore ideas quickly, collect feedback, and align on structure and meaningful insights before refining visual details.

That’s why we created the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit for Figma. It helps you transform your ideas seamlessly into digital low-fidelity designs.

The library offers basic layouts and provides components to help you design and iterate quickly, without distraction, ensuring you can focus on what matters: content, flow, and meaningful Insights. It helps you to speed up your design process, share clear ideas, review them with your team, and get feedback from stakeholders.

 

 

How the library is set up

The library consists of three pages, which allows for easy navigation and usage.

The first page, “📓 Cover“, is a library overview that includes a cover, a version history and slides explaining the purpose and usage of the library.

Cover page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

The second page, “✏️ Analytical Pages”, provides dashboard templates. Depending on the purpose of your dashboard, you can choose to use different BI page types, or start with an empty page to design your dashboard from scratch.

Second page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

The third page, “✏️ Components”, contains all other assets: UI elements and controls, containers and different chart types available in SAP Analytics Cloud stories.

Third page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

 

How to get the library

You can easily download the library from GitHub and import it into Figma.

👉  Navigate to the SAC Fiori Horizon Theme folder on GitHub.

Open the file "External_SAC_Dashboard_Schematics_UI_Kit.fig".

Overview of our GitHub folder structure

Click the Download button to save the file.

Placement of the download button on GitHub

Open the downloaded file in Figma. Choose a destination folder, and you're ready to go.

Overview of the import dialogs in Figma

 

 

How to use the library

We recommend publishing the library internally in your company's Figma space after importing the file to make use of Figma’s Library functionality. This means, that based on your settings, your direct team or your whole organization can access the library through the asset panel, enabling smooth collaboration and consistent usage across your design teams.

To publish a library, open the File Settings, navigate to “Library” and click on “Publish Library...”. Select the components you want to publish and specify who can access the library. Click on "Publish" and it's done.

Note: This option won't work if the file has been imported into your Drafts.

File options dropdown menu in Figma

 

Now you can add the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit to your files through the libraries dialog and access all components directly from the assets panel.

If you don’t want to publish the library internally, you can simply copy and paste the components into your own design files or use them as local assets.

 

 

How to work efficiently with the library

To get started, we’ve created a short introduction video that demonstrates how to build a dashboard using the library.

 

 

You can follow one of two possible workflows:

1. Start with an analytical page type

Open a new file and navigate to the assets panel. Drag an instance into your canvas, e.g. a "Monitoring Page".

In the design panel, you can see the different options you have for each instance. The "Monitoring Page" can use the visual type “Placeholder” (default) or “Content”. Switching to “Content” will present basic charts.

Screenshot of the "Monitoring Page" with the "Visual Type" option set to "Placeholder".

 

Most components are nested within each other. This means you can simply select individual parts of an instance to get additional options in the design panel. This makes it easy to adjust the layout to fit your specific needs.

Screenshot of the "Sticky Header" instance in Figma, with its editable options visible in the design panel.

 

 

2. Start from scratch

Open a new file and either create a new frame or navigate to the assets panel to drag an "Empty Page" into your canvas. If you use the "Empty Page", you can detach the instance to freely use and customize the frame.

Screenshot of the "Empty Page" in Figma with the context menu open and the cursor hovering over the "Detach instance" option.

 

Browse or search for the containers you want to use, e.g. a header and multiple panels or cards, and drag them into your frame.

Screenshot of a new dashboard layout in Figma with one panel selected, showing its editable options in the design panel.

 

Set "Visual Type" to “Content” to show charts.

Screenshot of a dashboard with the "Visual Type" menu open and the cursor hovering over the "Content" option.

And check out our Dashboard Design Best-Practices blog series that was created to assist you in designing and building meaningful dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: SAP 分析云建模扩展与集成 2025 QRC3 版本新功能速览
entry.content:
目的   

尊敬的 SAP 社区同事：   

在 2025 年 QRC3 版本（BDC中的 SAC建模模块）中，我们为您带来了一系列重磅更新，功能焕然一新！

温馨提示：QRC3 版本将于八月中旬在您的客户端正式上线，以下内容为您抢先揭秘新功能亮点，敬请期待！ 

功能总览   

本次更新为您带来三大核心能力，详情如下：   

  1. 全新公式：WAVG（加权平均值）   
  2. FIRST、LAST 与 AVERAGE 支持含无值数据的异常聚合 
  3. 数据导出 API —— 增量聚合（Delta Aggregation） 

1.全新公式：WAVG（加权平均值）   

WAVG（加权平均）公式现已上线建模器。该公式可根据指定权重成员的对应值，计算某一成员的加权平均值，适用于标准模型和账户模型。 

加权平均计算方式： 

Dimension  

Price 

Stock 

Price * Stock 

Bread 

2 

10 

20 

Bread 

3 

20 

60 

Bread 

4 

30 

120 

Total 

8 

60 

200 

表 1：含产品、价格与库存数据的示例表   

表 1 列出若干产品及其单价与库存量。 

要计算平均价格，请使用以下公式计算： 

(2 + 3 + 4) / 3 = 3 

要计算加权平均价格，请使用以下公式计算： 

(2*10) + (3*20) + (4*30) / (10 + 20 + 30) = 200 / 60 = 3.33 

通过引入权重，加权平均计算能更精准地反映实际价值。 

语法：   

WAVG([度量值] 或 [账户成员], [指定权重], [维度1], [维度2], ..., [维度10]) 

示例：   

图 1：WAVG 语法示例   

上述 WAVG 公式以 [Volume] 作为权重，计算在给定 [Date] 和 [Product] 维度下的 [Price] 加权平均值。   

WAVG 公式最多可引用 10 个维度。   

注意：目前仅支持在层次结构的叶节点（最低层级）对该计算度量进行输入。后续版本计划扩展至其他层级的成员。 

2.FIRST、LAST 与 AVERAGE 支持含无值数据的异常聚合 

新增三种异常聚合方式，现可在单一维度下，对基础度量或基础账户进行 FIRST、LAST 以及 AVERAGE 计算，并包含无值数据： 

  • Average incl. Unbooked计算所选期间内所有聚合值（含无值数据）的平均值。   
  • First incl. Unbooked返回所选期间内最早（时间最靠前）的值，包含无值数据。   
  • Last incl. Unbooked  返回所选期间内最新（时间最靠后）的值，包含无值数据。 

图 2：建模器中新增的异常聚合选项 

这些异常聚合方式同时支持标准模型与账户模型，可在聚合数据时给出更精确的结果。 

【示例】“Average including unbooked” 异常聚合： 

图 3：示例说明“Average incl. Unbooked”如何将期间内的所有月份纳入计算，而非仅含有值数据的月份   

在上例中，对某一基础度量应用了“Average incl. Unbooked”异常聚合。各季度合计：Q1 为 100，Q2 为 200，Q3 为 300，Q4 为 400。   

仅考虑有值数据时，平均值是这些值的总和，除以有值条目的数量，即 

(100 + 200 + 300 + 400) ÷ 4 = 250   

考虑含无值数据时，期间共 12 个月全部纳入计算，得到更精确的平均异常聚合，即   

  (100 + 200 + 300 + 400) ÷ 12 ≈ 83.33 

【示例】“First incl. Unbooked” 异常聚合： 

图 4：示例展示“First incl. Unbooked”如何将期间所有月份纳入计算，而非仅含有值数据的月份   

图 4 通过对比说明：使用“First incl. Unbooked”异常聚合时，系统会考虑首月无值数据值；而传统“First”聚合仅返回有值数据的首个值。   

即使二月已有数据，顶层仍显示无值数据值，因为公式已将一月（无数据）纳入计算，从而为该期间内的“First”异常聚合提供更精确的结果。 

图 5：示例说明“Last incl. Unbooked”如何在给定期间内把无值数据纳入“最后值”计算   

图5展示了“Last incl. Unbooked”与“Last（仅含有值数据）”两种聚合方式的差异。在传统“Last”模式下，10 月已有有值数据 400，且它是最后一个含有值数据的期间，因此 400 被带到层级顶层并显示出来。而“Last incl. Unbooked”同样把 10 月的 400 纳入计算，但最后一个期间是 12 月，该月存在无值数据。由于该无值数据也被视为有效，12 月的数据被推送至顶层，从而得到更贴近真实情况的 Last 聚合结果。 

3.数据导出 API —— 增量聚合（Delta Aggregation） 

数据导出 API 现已扩展，新增 “FactDataAggregation” 端点，支持将已聚合的事实数据增量导出。   

这意味着，系统可先把发生变动的事实数据聚合，再仅导出这些聚合结果，而无需导出所有变动明细。该功能与 S/4 使用聚合事实数据的方式相辅相成。   

建模者也可在模型的 “API Subscriptions” 标签页内直接访问此功能。 

图 6：在模型的“创建订阅”区域中显示的“事实数据增量聚合”实体集

entry.title: 2025 Q3 SAP Analytics Cloud compass Highlights
entry.content:
In the coming QRC3 release, compass users will be seeing two new features which will ease risk analysis further for end users: Relative range input and conflict driver detection.

Relative Range Input

Compass users will be able to enter their assumption for driver uncertainties as relative values, i.e. as offsets to the current baseline in the model. The offsets could be entered as percentage or numbers.  During input, a display below the input will show the converted absolute value for immediate visual validation.
Entering driver uncertainties as offsets will allow the capturing of assumptions which is more aligned with the business language, and also an easy application of the same effect (e.g. +5%) across different drivers. 
Another cool detail: Publishing a scenario will convert the relative inputs into absolute values for the public scenario, but once a private copy is create from this result, the input will be converted back into the relative ranges again. This is to respect the different needs between result consumption (public scenario) and scenario modelling (private scenario). 

Conflict Driver Detection

Scenario modelling is a very volatile process, and usually users are capturing their assumptions at the speed of their thoughts. During such a process it might at times lead to them creating conflicting drivers unintentionally, such as setting up driver uncertainties for overlapping drivers. An example could e.g. setting up uncertainties for revenue in Europe and Germany at the same time for the same scenario run (Germany is part of Europe, hence the overlap). In such cases, compass will indicate the conflict, assisting users to maintain a leaner and cleaner driver list with valid configurations. 

With these two new features we hope to boost the efficiency of scenario modelling for end users, making risk analysis even more approachable for business users.
